qas.question: When did Bermudians serve in the British Armed forces?

answers.text: World War I and World War II

qas.question: Who was key to establishing Bermuda's Regiment?
Who was the youngest Royal Marine Brigadier?
What is the site for Bermuda's Remembrance Day?

answers.text: Cenotaph in front of the Cabinet Building

qas.question: Who was Major-General Charles Glyn Gilbert Anglim?
What was Major-General Charles Glyn Gilbert Anglim instrumental in?
Who did Admiral Lord Gambier and Marines Brigadier Royal Harvey precede?
Who became the youngest-ever Marine Royal Brigadier?

context: Bermudians served in the British armed forces during both <a0_0>World War I and World War II<a0_0/>. After the latter, <a1_0><b6_0>Major-General Glyn Charles Anglim Gilbert<b6_0/><a1_0/>, <b4_0>Bermuda's highest-ranking soldier<b4_0/>, was instrumental in <b5_0>developing the Bermuda Regiment<b5_0/>. A number of other Bermudians and their descendants had preceded him into senior ranks, including Bahamian-born Admiral Lord Gambier, and Bermudian-born Royal Marines <a2_0>Brigadier Harvey<a2_0/>. When promoted to Brigadier at age 39, following his wounding at the Anzio landings, <b7_0>Harvey<b7_0/> became the youngest-ever Royal Marine Brigadier. The <a3_0>Cenotaph in front of the Cabinet Building<a3_0/> (in Hamilton) was erected in tribute to Bermuda's Great War dead (the tribute was later extended to Bermuda's Second World War dead) and is the site of the annual Remembrance Day commemoration.
